title: 112_hr198
content: The "Veterans Dog Training Therapy Act" establishes a pilot program within the Department of Veterans Affairs for dog training therapy. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program to assess the effectiveness of using training service dogs to address post-deployment mental health and post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms in veterans with disabilities. The program will run for five years at three to five VA medical centers. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program at selected medical centers to educate veterans with mental health conditions in service dog training. Training areas must be wheelchair accessible and include grooming space, training equipment storage, and classroom space. The pilot program for educating veterans with mental health conditions in service dog training includes wheelchair-accessible training areas with grooming, storage, classroom space, outdoor exercise, toileting space, and transportation for field trips. The program is administered through the Recreation Therapy Service of the Department of Veterans Affairs under the direction of a certified recreational therapist. The pilot program for educating veterans in service dog training requires a certified recreational therapist to oversee all sites, a director of service dog training with social services background, and certified training instructors at each site. The service dog training program requires instructors to select dogs with appropriate temperament and health clearances from shelters or foster homes. Dogs must be taught essential commands and live at the training site or a nearby foster home during training. The pilot program for service dog training involves lecture and hands-on training for veterans with disabilities to maximize therapeutic benefits. Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder or other mental health conditions can volunteer to participate. The pilot program allows veterans with disabilities to participate in service dog training if resources are available. Hiring preference is given to veterans who have graduated from treatment programs and received certification in service dog training. The Secretary will collect data on the program. The Secretary will collect data on the pilot program to determine its effectiveness for veterans, including reducing stigma, improving emotional regulation, patience, sense of purpose, helping fellow veterans, and community reintegration. The pilot program aims to help veterans by reintegrating them into the community, exposing them to new environments to reduce social isolation, building relationship and parenting skills, relaxing hyper-vigilance, improving sleep patterns, and decreasing the use of pain medication. The Secretary will report to Congress annually on the effectiveness of the program. The pilot program aims to help veterans by reintegrating them into the community and providing various services. The report to Congress will include the number of participants, services provided, and the effects on symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder and other relevant markers. The report to Congress will include the number of participants, services provided, effects on symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder, family dynamics, insomnia and pain management, overall well-being, and recommendations for program extension or expansion. The term "service dog training instructor" refers to an instructor who trains veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder in service dog training.
